Ah, it's the ""mirrors flip images" is a myth" myth. Mirrors do what's called "reflection"-- at least to the light that bounces off them. If you look at the image of your right hand through a mirror, it'll look like a left hand, no matter how you flip or turn it. If, on the other hand, you throw your left hand at a wall and it bounces off, it'll still look like a left hand, because walls don't reflect. Or do they?

Mirrors mirror objects about the mirror plane. I know it sounds obvious. But it's something most people don't get. If you reach out and touch the mirror, your hand appears as if it were a glove turned inside out. Imagine peeling a glove off into the space behind the glass. The result of this, is that any object with a chirality appears to be reversed. Right hand threads appear to be left. Your right hand appears to be your images left.  Etc. This is a result of mirroring a 3D object about a 2D plane.

Across from the Levites, the priests blew the trumpets, while all Israel stood.

7 Solomon then consecrated the central area of the courtyard in front of the Lord’s Temple. He offered burnt offerings and the fat of peace offerings there, because the bronze altar he had built could not hold all the burnt offerings, grain offerings, and sacrificial fat.

17 “As for you, if you faithfully follow me as David your father did, obeying all my commands, decrees, and regulations, 18 then I will establish the throne of your dynasty. For I made this covenant with your father, David, when I said, ‘One of your descendants will always rule over Israel.’

19 “But if you or your descendants abandon me and disobey the decrees and commands I have given you, and if you serve and worship other gods, 20 then I will uproot the people from this land that I have given them. I will reject this Temple that I have made holy to honor my name. This is inaccurate. First of all, if you were to write something and turn it in order to show them, they would see it perfectly. This is due to the fact that if you wrote it and saw it perfectly yourself, it's because the light is bouncing directly to your eyes. The same would happen if a friend saw it in your hands (it's only flipped for you). Think about if you were to show a mirror. The light goes towards it, and in order to get to your eyes, it has to change direction, causing the flip. Therefore, the mirror makes the flip, and not you.

Mirrors do reverse things though. Assuming you're facing North, then your reflection is facing South. Also when you see the front of the piece of paper, you see the back of its reflection. Also also when you rotate the piece of paper clockwise, its reflection rotates widdershins and vice versa.

A mirror flips not up and down nor left and right relative to itself, it flips front and back, that is the direction which it is facing. That's why the reflection of someone standing next to a lake on its surface is upside down; the surface of the lake, which is the mirror in this scenario, is facing up.

But what I was taught in science class long ago was everything we see is actually flipped upside down. Let me explain...
Everything we see are made of light reflected fr objects we look at, and our aqueous humour is curved (the front part of you eyes), it bends the light we see from the objects, creating an upside down image of what we see on the retina. But our brain eventually turns the image the right way to what we see now.

I have s serious objection to this "Mirrors don't flip anything" stuff.

Let's say you have an object: E
The mirror flips it. It becomes: ∃
Another mirror flips it again. It comes back the way it was: E

Now let's say the mirror does not flip anything.
You have the object ∃.
The mirror does not flip it. It stays the same way: ∃
Another does not flip it either. It stays the same way: ∃

Now, we already know that sending an image trough two mirrors makes the words look like we expected them to. Which means that the first scenario better reflects reality.
Images are flipped by mirrors, so much so that if it goes through two of them it is flipped twice and comes back to the way it was.
Pure logic:
E = E,
¬E = ¬E
¬¬E = E
THE MANS BACK

You may be thinking of Einstein's use of the phrase "For us believing physicists, the distinction between past, present and future is only a stubbornly persistent illusion." What he means is that all of space time - from the big bang to however things "end" - exists fully and completely all at once. Things don't "come into being" in the future or recede into the past - that's just an illusion. All of it exists right now, has since the beginning of space time, and never goes away. We just "travel" through it, and it is only our experience that makes it seem as if there's a difference between past and future, and hence an experience of "time."
Think of the entirety of spacetime as being a giant loaf of bread - at one crust slice is the start of spacetime, and the other crust slice is the end of spacetime. But the entire loaf exists all at once and came out of the oven fully baked - it's not changing at all. Imagine a tiny ant starting at the beginning crust and eating it's way through in a straight line from one end to the other. It can't back up and it can't change it's pace. It can only move steadily forward and with each bite it can only get sensory input from the part of the loaf it's sensory organs are touching. To the ant, it seems that each moment is unique, and while it may remember the moments from behind it, it hasn't yet experienced the moments to come. It seems there's a difference in the past and future, but the loaf is already there on both ends. Now what makes it weirder is that the ant itself is baked into the loaf from start to finish so in a sense it's merely "occupying" a new version of itself from one moment to the next. This also isn't quite right, since it's more accurate to say that the ant is a collection of all the separate moments the ant experiences. It's not an individual creature making it's way from one end to the other - it's the entire "history" of the creature from start to finish.
Conceptually difficult to grasp with our limited minds, and this has serious repercussions for the concept of free will, but those are different subjects for different discussions.
